Thomas Robbs wrote:

> Greetings Gurus... :-)
> 
> 
> 
> I have a problem trying to determine the "best practice" (ooo that dirty
> phrase) for this particular scenario.  Here is the sitatution:
> 
> 
> 
> Interface A   <------implements---- GenericClassA
> 
>      ^                                               ^
> 
>      |                                                |
> 
> extends                                     extends
> 
>      |                                               |
> 
>      |                                               |
> 
> Interface B   <------implements---- GenericClassB
> 
> 
> 
> Given the above, I want to create a new class that extends
> "GenericClassB", let's call it "Foo".   

I'm going to use shorter names to make it easier for myself. :)

Bad news: As far as I can see so far, no matter how you do this, you 
will have some runtime duplication in the tests. I would /really/ have 
to think about how to fix this.

Foo extends BImpl implements B
BImpl extends AImpl implements A

Here's where I put the various tests:

1. Tests for the contract of A go into Abstract Test Case ATestCase.
2. Tests for the non-A behavior in AImpl go into Concrete Test Case 
AImplTest extends ATestCase. This way, AImplTest includes tests both for 
AImpl itself and how well it satisfies the contract of A.

SIMILARLY...

3. Tests for the contract of B go into Abstract Test Case BTestCase, 
which extends ATestCase to include the contract tests for both A and B.
4. Tests for the non-B behavior in BImpl go into Concrete Test Case 
BImplTest which extends BTestCase.

FINALLY...

Tests for Foo-specific, non-B (and therefore non-A) behavior go into 
FooTest extends BImplTest. This way, FooTest inherits all the tests for 
the A and B interfaces.

Now, to your questions:

> 1.      Do I need to set up FooTest to ensure that I haven't broken the
> contract outlined by InterfaceA or InterfaceB?

I would.

> 2.      What's the best approach for setting up the tests so that I can
> do this, while still maximizing the value in having FooTest inherit from
> GenericClassBTest?

I think I outlined a good solution for this above.

> 1.      It's difficult for me to wrap my head around how to connect the
> initialization of the Test Fixture in the setUp() of the inner class to
> a factory method which will return an instance of the class under test,
> say at FooTest.createGenericClassB() when that inner class is in the
> super class.  

I can't wrap my head around that, because I can't understand it. You and 
I need to pair, dude.

 > Duplicating the inner class feels wrong and would be
> especially painful if the inheritance tree was long and it was up to the
> Programmer to research the inheritance and insure that they have inner
> class for all possible interfaces.
